;Recently, according to the official website of China Banking and Insurance Information Technology Management Co., Ltd. (hereinafter referred to as "China Banking and Insurance"), The list of personal pension insurance products has been expanded to 69 products, involving 22 insurance companies.

;

;It is worth mentioning that this expansion not only added 3 new product types to the 48 at the end of July, but also added 18 personal tax-deferred pension annuity insurance (hereinafter referred to as "tax "Extended Pension Products") has been incorporated into the personal pension product system. After the expansion, the types of personal pension insurance products include exclusive commercial pension insurance, endowment insurance, annuity insurance and tax-deferred pension products.

;

;;;

;;(Picture source: China Bank & Credit Insurance Co., Ltd.);

;

;The above 18 items are included in personal pension Financial tax-deferred pension products are provided by China Pacific Life Insurance Co., Ltd., Taiping Pension Insurance Co., Ltd., Ping An Pension Insurance Co., Ltd., Taikang Pension Insurance Co., Ltd., Taiping Life Insurance Co., Ltd. and Generali Life Insurance Co., Ltd.

;

;The Kaiyuan Securities research report shows that the integration of tax-deferred commercial pension insurance into personal pensions mainly helps policyholders of tax-deferred pension insurance to coordinate and unify the third pillar tax preferential policies and reduce the personal income tax rate when receiving them. , which is conducive to the further improvement of the personal pension system.

;

;Previously, on August 31, the State Financial Supervision and Administration Bureau issued the "Notice on Matters Concerning the Connection between the Pilot Program of Personal Tax-Deferred Commercial Pension Insurance and Personal Pensions." The main content of the "Notice" includes clarifying the work requirements, business adjustments, product management, policy transfer, etc. in the process of connecting the tax-deferred pension insurance pilot and personal pensions, and also clarifies the customer information confirmation and strengthens system construction for China Banking and Credit Insurance Co., Ltd. , as well as requirements for business operations, announcements and information submissions of tax-deferred pension insurance pilot insurance companies. In principle, all work should be completed before the end of 2023.

;

;Industry insiders said that personal tax-deferred pension insurance highlights the "burden reduction" effect, and the tax burden after retirement is lighter. The expansion of the list means that the connection between the tax-deferred pension insurance business and the personal pension system is progressing in an orderly manner, in line with work expectations.

;

;As early as 2018, the Ministry of Finance and other departments jointly issued the "Notice on Launching the Pilot of Personal Tax-Deferred Commercial Pension Insurance", launching the pilot business operation in the country. The pilot areas are Shanghai, Fujian and Suzhou Industrial Parks, and the maximum pre-tax deduction amount is 6% of personal taxable income or 12,000 yuan per year, whichever is lower.

;

;Ping An Securities stated that the pilot policy is not attractive to low-income people, and the tax benefits are limited for those who can enjoy tax benefits. Under the personal pension system, there are more product choices and simpler tax deduction procedures. The two types of products have similar attributes and share tax preferential quotas. The integration of tax-deferred commercial pension insurance into personal pensions will straighten out the relationship between tax-advantaged pension insurance. Relevant procedures will be simplified to make it easier for investors to understand. At the same time, it will further enrich the selection of personal pension products and increase investors' willingness to insure.

;

;Since the official implementation of the personal pension system in November 2022, personal pension insurance products have continued to expand. According to the official website of China Banking and Insurance Corporation, by the end of July 2023, the number of personal pension insurance products has increased from The initial 7 models were expanded to 48 products, and currently it has been expanded to 69 products.

;

;Ping An Securities stated that residents’ demand for retirement savings continues to expand under the background of an aging population. However, since this year, long-term interest rates have remained low and volatile, many commercial banks have lowered deposit interest rates, the equity market has fluctuated greatly, and the returns of competing products have Rates have declined, and insurance products follow pricing interest rates, have guaranteed yields, and can provide protection against risks such as death, total disability, and disability, further highlighting their differentiated advantages. As an important part of the third pillar of pension insurance, commercial pension insurance is expected to achieve rapid development under the personal pension system.

;

;For details of relevant reports, please see: "< a href="https://www.infzm.com/contents/258684" title="Documentary "The Nest": Why do two generations who torture each other still live together">;Documentary "The Nest": Two generations who torture each other Why do modern people still live together;》

;

;The documentary "The Nest" focuses on a family of three in Shanghai. A young man born in 1985 graduated from school many years ago and lives with his parents in a 30-square-meter apartment. Husband’s room. Liu Wenrong, a researcher at the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences, paid attention to this documentary. She is very familiar with such families. 2016 was the year when the documentary started to be filmed. She was doing research on intergenerational relations at the time and discovered the group of families that “gnaw at the elderly”: “There were already many such cases in 2016, but now the employment situation of young people is more difficult. Severe, and their expectations are different, so there are more and more people. The earliest was in 2005 or 2006, Shanghai started to 'gnaw', because housing prices became more expensive, and the elderly felt more and more pressure to support their children. When I came to college, there was a wave of discussion about the issue of 'gnawing at the elderly.'"

;

;Liu Wenrong began to pay attention to and study the intergenerational relationship issues in Chinese society when she was studying for her Ph.D. In the first decade of the 21st century, scholars engaged in qualitative research devoted a lot of space to discussing issues such as the decline of filial piety, the pension crisis, and intergenerational imbalance. Her doctoral thesis that year also stemmed from wanting to test the theory of "the decline of filial piety," but it led her in another direction. In 2008, when she analyzed survey data from Lanzhou and Shanghai, she found that intergenerational relationships were getting closer, and that younger people were more likely to agree with the concept of filial piety.

;

;From 2012 to 2019, she and the research team visited Shanghai, Lanzhou, Dalian and other places, collected 137 family cases, and collected 11 family cases in the United States. Combined with the sample survey data, she finally came to the conclusion: Social transformation has strengthened the emotional structure of "parent-child integration" in Chinese families. The tradition of intergenerational mutual aid has shown strong resilience. Intergenerational ties still play a community role in settling individual lives and motivating daily life.

;

;During field research, Liu Wenrong met many Chinese young people who were supported and supported by their families. During her research in the United States, she communicated with local scholars and saw the contrast between Eastern and Western families. touch. In addition, she has the identity and experience of a mother, and her mentality has changed. In the past, she was disgusted with China's family culture and believed that "moral kidnapping" was too heavy. Now she believes that this is a warm system design. Chinese urban families bear the burden of young people's unemployment, marriage and childbearing.

;

;;

;

;;In the documentary "The Nest", the protagonist born in 1985 (left) lives with his parents who are over 70 years old. Photo courtesy of the film producer;;);

;

;“Although our previous cultural ideals were freedom and equality, the elimination of feudal filial piety and intergenerational patriarchy, etc., in reality Society, apart from these, has not established other cultural and spiritual foundations that can support people to settle down and live a life, so (family culture) has become a value demonstration. We must respect the inheritance of culture and transform it. This does not mean that transformation is What can be transformed requires profound ideological transformation, which is a relatively long process." Liu Wenrong told Southern Weekend reporters.

;

;Currently, Liu Wenrong has shifted her research focus to young people’s marriage and love, and is working on the topic “Research on the Trends, Dilemmas and Social Processes of Marriage and Love among Young People in Big Cities”. In an interview with Southern Weekend reporters, she talked about intergenerational conflicts in families in transition, the phenomenon of stay-at-home sons and daughters, and the plight of youth in the information society, among other topics. The following is his self-report:

;

;Once children no longer get married and have children, it will be difficult for them to truly reconcile with their parents

;

;For those of us born in the 1970s, especially in our youth, we have very Strong motivation to leave home. why? Parental control is very painful, and the love we feel is very little, because when you have many children, your parents allocate very little time and energy, including financial resources. In this state, children do not need to be evaluated. It is almost a natural motivation, that is, they must study away from them at a very early age, and they must earn money to support themselves. This motivation is very strong. You must also get married, because once you get married, you can leave that family with confidence.

;

;Under this dynamic, it can be said that we were all a matter of survival at that time. We also want self-realization. Since childhood, we have thought about painting, singing, writing, etc., but most people just regard it as an ideal buried in their hearts. First of all, you must meet your own needs, find a job, get married, and have a support network of peers in society. Our support mainly relies on friends and classmates. This network is very important, and we are willing to spend time and energy to make such relationships.

;

;But today's young people have very little pressure to survive from their parents. They spend a lot of energy and thoughts on why their ideals cannot be realized, which makes them very powerless, because they The standard of self-realization is relatively high.

;

;Although I think young people will be unhappy if such words are said, I know that their experiences are different and they cannot understand. My research also found that it is difficult for generations to understand each other because they do not have similar experiences or similar social roles. They have to rely more on their parents because their parents are more mature than them. For example, a harmonious family relies on the compromises of the parents. Whether it is done naturally or shaped after reflection, it must have achieved profound ideological comfort and tolerance. Without this, it would be difficult, because the children do not have similar life paths and experiences, and it is difficult to reach spiritual reconciliation with their parents. Even if they also agree with filial piety and the importance of love, it is difficult to produce such a thing.

;

;So this is also a dilemma that families have on people's spirits, especially now that after the transformation, the path of life is no longer standardized or copied, and each person is individualized. I later published a book specifically discussing the emotional transformation of intergenerational relationships in Chinese families. My final conclusion was to talk about the role of childbirth in the value recognition and emotional communication between two generations. Many young people only reach spiritual reconciliation with their parents after they get married and have children. If he has not become a parent, it will be difficult for him to truly understand his parents and let go of the harm his parents have done to him. Only when he stands in the same role and has his own emotional experience with his children, can he truly realize the difficulties of being a parent, and find that no matter how good his intentions are, there are still many dissatisfactions and many unsatisfactory things. He cannot control the situation and cannot be a perfect parent. At this time, he can let go of some things his parents did in his upbringing and understand that the upbringing process is not easy. This reconciliation is actually very subtle. During my investigation, parents will naturally feel the tacit understanding between them (and their children), and they will feel relieved mentally.

;

;Why do Chinese parents care so much about their children getting married and having children? The issue of carrying on the family line is basically not emphasized by Chinese parents nowadays. They think it is a feudal idea, especially educated parents. But why do I still pursue this thing? I always feel that there is something wrong with it, that is, the difficult path of becoming a parent is not recognized. This is a huge loss in their value, and this sense of loss cannot be expressed in the modern value system. Parents don’t talk about these things on the Internet, and even in daily life, they don’t know why they are like this. In fact, it's because I haven't been recognized, and I don't know what I have been busy with all my life. But when children give birth to children, they get a kind of spiritual understanding and relief, and a recognition of value. This is very important.

;

;The vitality of Chinese family culture lies in inheritance, which is a cycle, not linear. But once children no longer get married and have children, it is actually difficult for them to understand the struggles in marriage and parenting, and it is difficult for them to truly reconcile with their parents psychologically. Therefore, I think the culture of voluntary non-marriage and childbearing that is emerging among young people is a very big challenge that Chinese families are currently facing in the social transformation.

;

;We have all experienced a period of rapid economic development, and there was not such strong information dissemination in adolescence. We also naturally enjoyed the dividends of the development of this era without any deliberate reflection. But today's young people grow up in a completely different stage of social development, and they face very big spiritual challenges. We need more intergenerational understanding. We cannot say that today's teenagers are all hypocritical and nihilistic, that they are flat, have no ambition, or are lazy. In every era there are people who are unable to enter society because of some psychological or personality problems. But if this group of people is particularly large, it becomes a social problem. What we need is understanding and communication between generations.

;

;For example, we are also worried about the issue of marriage and love among young people. The mainstream society is very worried, and the country is also very worried. Why are we not willing to get married? Why don't you want to have children? I think it is more important to understand that it is important to make young people recognize the path of marriage and having children from their hearts, and to tell them the significance of intimate relationships to people's mental health and long-term development. Because being unmarried and having children is mostly a form of self-protection for young people who are under a sense of risk. If they lack support, they can only focus on the present. Therefore, we need to think about the spirituality and psychology of family life in an all-round way culturally. Or, more society-wide discussions are needed so that everyone can have more understanding of the institution of marriage and intimate relationships, and create more possibilities and space for personal path choices. Our government has always said that it supports marriage and childbearing by providing money and time. I think there is also a need for more guidance on the value aspect, or for young people to recognize it more.

;

;“What we worry about is that young people will never be able to leave the family”

;

;In urban middle-class families, children born after 1995 are more likely to return to their parents. My article, "The Return of Parental Rights and the Reconstruction of Filial Piety in Urban Families in the Transformation Period," is a response to the phenomenon that there are more and more "mama's babies" and children are willing to listen to their parents for many things and have a close relationship and emotional intimacy with their parents. In daily life, they are a little rebellious, but there is no conflict with their parents on major issues. Whether it is the concept of choosing a spouse, the concept of employment, or the concept of entering school, they seem to be very similar.

;

;For middle-class parents, they have completely changed the past "paternalistic" parenting model. In the article, I call it reflexive parenting practice, which is when parents reflect on the pain in their own growth experiences, form a parenting style based on love and emotion, and comprehensively plan and plan the growth path of their children. Help and hope your children will be happy and successful. On the other hand, even middle-class parents have different resources. Parents born in the 1980s and those born in the 1950s have not accumulated much wealth and are still under great financial pressure. But things are different after 1995. The economic situation of the entire society has developed greatly, especially those who are middle-class or above and have college-educated parents. They generally have better careers, better economic accumulation, and better knowledge accumulation. Socially The capital and economic capital are relatively good in all aspects, so I can devote myself to the upbringing of my children in an all-round way, and it is a kind of close parenting and intensive upbringing since childhood. This kind of intimate parenting uses emotional influence and guidance, and there is less brutal coercive control behavior. Therefore, children do not have so much tension and conflict with their parents when they grow up, and even in adolescence they still show a high degree of dependence on their parents.

;

;I feel that mental health problems are particularly serious among those born in the 2000s and 10s. This is of course related to academics, but it is also closely related to the long-term family structure, that is, the symbiosis between generations. The child was cared for and packed with love that took his breath away. Whether children are at school or at home, they are completely monitored. In this case, it will be difficult for children to be mentally healthy, and they will have a strong sense of powerlessness, so depression among teenagers is also increasing.

;

;Our Chinese familism is the state of parent-child integration, which has a strong instrumental function in life support. For example, in the process of my country's economic transformation, there has not been a large number of young people living in poverty, all of whom are supported by their parents. There has not been a large number of young people who cannot get married, have fallen into poverty, or even become homeless. This is all because of the lack of parental support in Chinese families. On the bottom, so this is a benefit in a tool sense. But now that we are in the second decade of the 21st century, what we see is more mental pressure and pressure on the development of young people. What we are worried about is that young people will never be able to get out of their families and are trapped inside.

;

;Japan also has a similar situation. When economic development slows down or even stagnates, young people have fewer opportunities to obtain stable and good jobs and good marriages. Parents protect their children. They call it the phenomenon of "staying single". They just stay with their parents, never get married, and some of them don't even work. I read some information and found that these children who have been single until old age are likely to fall into a state of singlelessness after the death of their parents, which is also a very big social problem. Will we also reach this point? What should we do when human survival is no longer a problem and development faces bottlenecks? Is it a way out for parents to protect their children?

;

;I have no objection to children having full-time jobs, but parents should be smart parents and their children should be smart children. There is no problem with periodic gaps, because now you have the conditions to pursue a better career, a higher education, and a better marriage partner. The period of adulthood will inevitably become longer and longer, but you must realize that you cannot Always like this. Childhood status is indefinite, but as a full-time child, there is a concept of a contract. I can terminate the contract and change jobs. It is a profession, temporary, not lifelong.

;

;Both parents and children must make their own preparations for changing jobs or changing professional status. They cannot just accept this state of mind by saying "I am fine this way" and keep it like this. Unless you are engaged in a creative job, (for example) writing at home, but you still have to have a way to support yourself, because if your source of value is not independent, your self-efficacy will definitely be very low, and it will definitely be from a mental health point of view. Not a long-term solution.

;

;Westerners summarize the Chinese family as a corporation model - thinking that the Chinese family is a cooperative. In fact, a corporation is also an organization based on a rational structure and a business. Organizations and careers need to develop, and development needs to continue to grow. But I think these young people have not inherited this familialist view. They have reduced their efforts to build a larger intimate circle because the risks from the outside world are too great. In fact, for their families, there is no development and no future. In other words, between these two generations, it is over when it is over. This is not our Chinese familism tradition. He is just satisfied with his simplest idea of ​​filial piety, that is, I am a good person, I honor my parents, my parents love me, and I love them too. I work hard to make my parents live a good life, and that's it. The moral value of my life. Therefore, this "return to filial piety" is indeed the true state of mind of today's young people, but it is by no means a simple return to tradition.

;

;This trend makes people live a very abstract life

;

;Nowadays, young people have relatively high demands, including the standards for marriage and love, which are very complicated. I support young people's spiritual pursuits and love pursuits, but it is difficult to add practical considerations to these pursuits. When I did research on marriage and love, I found that all the investigators had no way to avoid it. In the end, choosing a spouse was an economic indicator, but economics alone could not completely convince them, so they were very confused. The psychological complexity is very strong. Unlike those of us born in the 1970s who have a very strong drive to leave home, we really don’t think about it that much. Because families with many children at that time had limited resources and parents were generally impatient with their children, young people had to go to other places to go to school, get a job, get married, and build their own life network. Behind this was a motivation closer to survival needs, so they had to work hard. , the partner's pursuit of idealization and perfection is relatively weak.

;

;But now the information and reference standards of the entire society are different. The current network and information dissemination are too developed, giving people a strong sense of powerlessness. You always feel that there are endless possibilities, but the reality is not like that. The people he refers to are always the best ones. He cannot be satisfied with the people and things around him, including himself, and lives a very unhappy life.

;

;In this case, it will be difficult for young people to live in the concrete life in front of them, causing them to fall into a great sense of powerlessness. "I will not settle, I will work hard" is both a personality statement and a risk aversion. In fact, they don't work hard because there is no way to work hard. Human energy and strength are limited, and you can only work hard near yourself. As the old saying goes, you have to do it step by step.

;

;It was easy for us to do it back then, but why is it so difficult for young people to do it now? It’s not that young people are bad, it’s because changes in the entire society have led to changes in people’s psychological environment. Therefore, if you want to do some reverse self-training, you must do it through deliberate, conscious, and profound self-discipline. You cannot do it if you follow this trend. Because under this trend, there seems to be a cultural environment that makes people live very abstract and unrealistic lives. At that time, even if we were looking for a job, we didn't seem to feel uncomfortable or uncomfortable, because everyone was like this, it was not unacceptable, and most people were in this state. This is also the progress of a society. Survival is no longer a problem. Only now young people will think, "I don't want to settle, I want to pursue my own most ideal state."

;

;There is also the background of a risk society, which is caused by fear. This is also very important. We have to look at where a young person focuses his attention. The higher he focuses his attention, the more fearful he will be, and the stronger his sense of powerlessness will be. But this era is an attention economy, and what attracts people is always those lofty things. Consumerism and Internet culture are all like this. Most of them satisfy people's physiological stimulation and stimulate people's desires. This desire will temporarily make you excited or satisfied, or create a beautiful imagination, but it It will not support you step by step in life for a long time. That’s why I say that young people live very abstract lives. I don’t want to use other words, such as derogatory words such as impetuous.

;

;It has become very difficult to "adult" now. It is very difficult to identify and stabilize oneself. Of course, people have to be in this process of getting to know themselves throughout their lives, but it is difficult for a young person to enter the next stage of growth because he cannot distinguish, cannot make a choice, and is always in this entangled state. And today's Internet culture, consumer culture, and games all make young people indulge in this stage more and more, and they remain underage.

;

;They have always been unable to distinguish between desires and ideals: in fact, they are satisfying their short-term desires, not walking on the ideal path, because they have not been implemented in reality. The atmosphere created by our culture makes them feel that they are on this road, creating the illusion that they are very pursuing, ideal, and struggling. In this way, they miss the best state of their life cycle and slowly and naturally slide. In fact, many studies have noticed, including Japanese research and surveys on youth, that it is not that young people plan to remain unmarried and have children. They firmly establish "I am an unmarried and infertile person" from the beginning. Yes, but it is not a big deal. most people. It's just that in the process of looking for a partner and exploring their own ideals, they slipped to the end of being single.

;

;I think young people still need to have a better understanding. It is indeed the influence of the entire environment. Social, cultural, psychological, and economic aspects are actually an oppression of the human spirit by the entire modernity. If you go further up, you will reach this (level), which is very obvious among young people.

;

;Nowadays young people do not have the opportunity to fall in love for a long time

;

;When you are in your twenties, you seem to have unlimited possibilities, and when you are forty, it seems that there are still many possibilities. But the fact that you are in reality and look around you and there seems to be no chance is very frustrating.

;

;I did research on marriage and love, and found that young people think there are many opportunities and there are many platforms on the Internet. There seem to be a lot of choices, but in the end, none of them are choices, or there is no way to become a realistic choice. This is the dilemma of young people.

;

;This choice is different from what we had back then. Let me just talk about one point. It’s very interesting that college students don’t fall in love now, but high school students seem to still do it. But why don’t they fall in love in college? Moreover, they don’t seek help from their own units after they start working, because they will feel embarrassed if they fail! This reason sounds incredible at first, but when I think about it carefully, I think it is quite right. It is very rational.

;

;Love requires time, emotional cultivation, and long-term contact with each other. My investigation revealed that they work very hard to go on blind dates every weekend and only once a week. They rack their brains to talk to people and even participate in various blind dates. But after the event is over, that person will no longer be around you. Even if you think this person is okay at the time, if he doesn't appear next to you within this week, you will see him again on the weekend at most. Many people will stick to it for two or three times and then it will be boring. And the key is that the conditions will not be so good that you will be desperate. The conditions may be okay, but if you think about it again, there are still many things you are not satisfied with.

;

;This is a rational measurement. If you measure based on conditions, you will always be dissatisfied. It is impossible for a person to be good at everything and fully meet all conditions. The long-term relationship does not depend on the conditions. Even if the conditions are average but there is love, they will be together. This is often the case. But now young people don't have this opportunity, they don't have the opportunity to develop feelings, because they have no daily contact at all, and even some events happen to touch you. In this case, if you don't have feelings, you will completely depend on the conditions, and you will always be dissatisfied depending on the conditions, so it will be difficult.

;

;This society seems to have a lot of choices, but in fact because you have no real contact, there are few opportunities and few options nearby. Moreover, they are afraid of entering specific relationships in real life. They are very afraid of the risk of relationship breakdown or unhappiness. They are worried about being hurt and entangled in the relationship. They are very worried and wary about investing in interpersonal relationships.

;

;I don’t know if this is a common problem among only children. That is, they have a strong sense of interpersonal boundaries. They are worried and afraid of complicated relationships, and naturally form a distance from others. They want to choose themselves wherever they go. come out. And in our era of having many children, we have been involved in various relationships since we were young, and we must have suffered a lot. However, it seems that we have naturally developed a lack of fear, thinking that this is a normal state, or developing a physiological response to cope with it. Okay, so are the skills. Nowadays, young people who are protected by their parents, or only children, do not have this ability, and they are not willing to get involved in interpersonal relationships. They think that is very low, they like to be alone, and they need their own space. So I think these are all changes of the times and a negative consequence of the progress of the times.

;

;One of my students said that she just needs to be with her parents. There are indeed such children and such thoughts: I don’t need to establish such a strong and close relationship with anyone in this world. Because building a close relationship requires a lot of adjustment, a lot of discomfort, and very big challenges. Tolerance and various compromises between people, in short, they are not willing to do it. They think it is too complicated. They can play with it once or twice, but it is difficult to have in-depth communication. So I think they would rather go on a blind date. Some students even said, Teacher, it would be great if the country gave us a spouse. They are willing to follow dramas and have sex, and the sweetness of love is used up, and they no longer need to find the feeling of love in real life. Because there is no such perfect person, let him have that kind of emotion, thinking that two people are so sweet and in love with each other.

;

;Looking at others falling in love, if you want to start a family, "the country will send me one." So they are very receptive to introductions from their parents. Of course, their parents' values ​​are relatively close to theirs, and they can coordinate their opinions on mate selection, so they accept their parents' arrangements, which is completely different from what we expected at the time. What we originally thought was that with the development of modernization and the improvement of education, marriage must be a free love model. But it doesn't seem to be the case now. Love is love, but marriage is well arranged by parents.

;

;Of course, this is not a large-scale survey, and it may be difficult to reflect it in a large-scale survey. But I have seen national survey data before, which shows that compared with the 1990s, the role of parents in their children's marriage decisions has increased after the 21st century. I think this is natural, mainly for economic reasons. Nowadays, when young people get married, they have to rely on their parents for every step of buying a house, giving gifts, and looking after children. In addition, young people's psychological dependence on their parents has also increased, so parents' voice will definitely increase.

; Fri, 20 Oct 2023 16:25:03 +0800 改什么？怎么改？难在哪？超大特大城市城中村改造政策解读http://www.infzm.com/contents/258861

;

;Since this year, the transformation of urban villages has pressed the "acceleration button". The Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development recently stated that very large and megacities are actively and steadily advancing the transformation of urban villages, and the implementation is divided into three categories.

;

;As a systematic livelihood project and development project involving the interests of many parties, what is the current background for promoting the transformation of urban villages in very large and megacities? How to change it? What's the difficulty? "Xinhua Viewpoint" reporters interviewed experts and scholars in the industry.

;

;;;Why change? ;;

;

;Since this year, the transformation of urban villages has attracted much attention. The Political Bureau meeting of the CPC Central Committee held on April 28 put forward the requirement to "actively and steadily promote the transformation of urban villages in very large and megacities"; in July, the General Office of the State Council issued the "Guiding Opinions on Actively and Steadily Promoting the Transformation of Urban Villages in Very Large and Megacities" , and held a video and telephone conference for special deployment.

;

;Recently, the Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development has proposed specific policy implementation measures for the transformation of urban villages, which are divided into three categories: one is to implement demolition and new construction if conditions are met, and the other is to carry out regular renovation and improvement , the third category is the combination of implementation and integration between the two.

;

;Urban villages are called "villages in the city". They have the dual characteristics of rural and urban areas and are a historical product of the development process of urbanization.

;

;Take Hongqi Village in Putuo District, the largest urban village in central Shanghai, as an example. On 586 acres of land, there were once gathered 90 printing factories, 207 cold storages, and 9 large primary markets. , more than 1,000 stalls, the population here is complex, rented by tenants all over the place, illegal buildings are densely covered, and the floating population is as high as 60,000.

;

;According to relevant standards, cities with an urban resident population of more than 10 million are considered megacities, such as Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, Shenzhen, Chengdu, Chongqing, Tianjin, Wuhan, etc.; cities with an urban resident population of more than 5 million are classified as megacities. The following cities are megacities, such as Qingdao, Hefei, Hangzhou, Changsha, Nanjing, Dongguan, etc. A total of more than 20 cities across the country belong to the category of megacities.

;

;“my country’s megacities have absorbed a large number of migrant populations, and a considerable number of these groups rent in urban villages. Although the cost of renting in urban villages is lower, they generally lack necessary infrastructure and public services, especially There are many hidden dangers in terms of health safety and social governance," said Yu Xiaofen, dean of the China Housing and Real Estate Research Institute of Zhejiang University of Technology.

;

;Yan Rong, president of the Shanghai Academy of Real Estate Sciences, said that promoting the transformation of urban villages can play a positive role in stabilizing economic growth and become an important driver of expanding domestic demand, generating more than 10 trillion yuan. Direct investment and boost consumption of furniture, home appliances, catering services, textiles, etc.; on the other hand, it can optimize the urban spatial layout and further improve the level of urban governance.

;

;;;How to change it? ;;

;

;“The property rights structure, personnel composition, spatial distribution, historical relics, etc. of urban villages are highly complex. This reconstruction proposes three types of demolition and new construction, renovation and improvement, and combination of demolition and reorganization. Transformation model." Li Yujia, deputy director of the Guangdong Provincial Housing Policy Research Center, said that urban villages that meet the conditions, that is, have balanced funds, strong public willingness to transform, and clear land and property rights, will be demolished and built; those that do not meet the conditions will not be forced to build new ones. On the basis of the principle of keeping the bottom line of safety, rectification and improvement are carried out on a regular basis, and reforms are implemented after gradually solving problems.

;

;In terms of transformation methods, the current urban village transformation particularly emphasizes the need to combine the protection of villagers’ legitimate rights and interests with planning before taking action.

;

;Yu Xiaofen said that the New Deal emphasizes that transformation can be implemented only with the consent of the majority of villagers. Before the transformation, local governments must first make preliminary planning work such as relocating industries, properly resettling personnel, protecting historical and cultural features, and securing funds. During renovation, the land supply and construction of the resettlement housing project should be arranged in advance to ensure that the resettlement housing is completed within a reasonable period of time, the quality is not lower than that of commercial housing, and the supporting infrastructure and public service facilities are in line with the planning, design, approval, construction, and delivery of the resettlement housing. Use the "five synchronizations" to effectively protect the interests of villagers.

;

;“Urban villages are highly complex social complexes and should maintain diversified business formats after renovation.” Zhao Yanjing, vice president of the China Urban Planning Society, said that the urban village itself is an industrial space, and its business formats are not pre-planned. planning, but constantly changing as market demands change. The transformation of urban villages should focus on the introduction and cultivation of industries, and strive to develop various business formats.

;

;;;;

;

;; Imposition photo: The picture above shows the transformed Hefei, Anhui Province, taken on August 3, 2023 Renovation project of Antuodong Village and Xinzhuang Urban Village in Yaohai District of the city (drone photo); the picture below shows the old appearance of Antuodong Village and Xinzhuang Urban Village before renovation in March 2015. Xinhua News Agency (Photo by Xie Chen) ;

;

;Li Yujia said that in the past, urban village reconstruction was market-led, with selectivity and selection. Those with high economic value were included in the reconstruction plan, while there were many problems left over from history and safety issues. Those with high hidden risks were left alone. "This time, all urban villages must be included in the scope of reconstruction. When expropriating and demolishing, we cannot only calculate the economic accounts and only expropriate land plots with high economic value and few problems. Instead, we must expropriate all the land regardless of whether it is good or bad, and completely solve the problem of urban villages. And prevent the emergence of new urban villages.”

;

;This urban village transformation requires that in principle, affordable housing should be built in a certain proportion.

;

;In this regard, Zhao Yanjing said that one of the important functions of urban villages in the city is to provide rental affordable housing for the floating population. Urban villages have actually become an integral part of the affordable housing system. "If the supply of affordable housing is reduced after the renovation, the living environment of the floating population deteriorates, and the rents are higher, then the original intention of urban village transformation will not be achieved. Therefore, affordable housing must be built in a certain proportion in the renovation plan as compensation."

;

;;;What issues should be paid attention to during renovation? ;;

;

;In interviews, experts generally believed that special attention should be paid to three issues when promoting the transformation of urban villages:

;

;First, the issue of demolition and resettlement. Yu Xiaofen said that urban villages left behind by megacities have many illegal buildings, dense populations, and complex property rights relationships, which are the "hard bones" that are difficult to transform. Issues such as demolition and compensation are very complicated, and there are many contradictions and uncertainties.

;

;The reporter learned from interviews in various places that almost all kinds of economic activities are available in urban villages in very large and megacities.

;

;"In reality, urban villages have formed complementary functions in the long-term interaction with other functions of the city. Simply 'cutting off' the urban villages will cause other parts of the city to become disabled. We must be particularly cautious about this. ." Zhao Yanjing said.

;

;Zhao Yanjing believes that at the beginning of the transformation, it is necessary to conduct careful research and analysis on the urban functions performed by urban villages. If you cannot find an alternative to these functions, do not rush to "resection" surgery. At this time, "minimally invasive" conservative treatment should be used.

;

;The second is the issue of fund balance and financing. Yu Xiaofen said that the remaining urban villages have high building density and high resettlement costs, especially in the current environment where the real estate market outside megacities is still relatively sluggish. Compared with the past, the value of the land transferred after the transformation of urban villages has declined, which will inevitably increase the social impact. Difficulty in raising capital.

;

; "The key to how to overcome the 'hard nut' in urban village transformation is how to balance the transformation funds." Li Yujia said that the guidance issued by the General Office of the State Council proposed to encourage the implementation of regional coordination and development in large areas, and the land for transformation projects should be divided into four areas. The scope can be expanded to a small amount of surrounding low-efficiency land, allowing the integration and replacement of collective land and state-owned land. "In other words, local governments can change the 'small balance' of the past single urban village transformation into the 'big balance' of comprehensive transformation of the area, using abundance to make up for the deficit, and using fat to make up for the thin."

;

;Zhao Yanjing said , the urban village renovation must innovate the renovation model, seek diverse financing channels, encourage and support the participation of private capital, of which the participation of the original property owners is particularly important.

;

;The third is standards and normative constraints. Some urban villages that do not meet the conditions for demolition have implemented partial demolition and comprehensive renovation, requiring improvement and management in accordance with civilized city standards. This is a problem for some houses with poor quality, low standards, high renovation costs, and unclear property rights of some houses. Urban villages with incomplete procedures are challenging.

;

;“The transformation of urban villages requires planning before action, overall planning, overall planning, and active and steady advancement. We must use new ideas and new methods to solve the problem of how to calculate the accounts, how to use money, how to acquire land, and how to recruit people in the transformation of urban villages. and how to relocate industries, and explore a new way to transform urban villages under the new situation." said Chai Qiang, president of the China Society of Real Estate Appraisers and Real Estate Agents.

; Fri, 20 Oct 2023 15:25:03 +0800 城市排名，看看就行http://www.infzm.com/contents/258754
;;2023-10-20 14:00:00;
;

;Recently, the consulting company Resonance Consultancy released the "Ranking of the World's Best Cities in 2024". 2024 has not arrived yet, but the ranking is so forward-looking.

;

;In this ranking, the top ones are: London, Paris, New York, Tokyo, Singapore, Dubai, San Francisco, Barcelona, ​​Amsterdam, Seoul, Rome, Prague, Madrid, Berlin, Los Angeles, and Washington. Then there is Beijing, ranked 18th.

;

;Some netizens sarcastically asked, did this list take into account the rarity of drug dealing, shootings, explosions, robberies, thefts, etc.? Nowadays, I increasingly don’t believe in the various rankings selected by foreigners. In some cities, local friends told me not to go out at night before I even went there.

;

;The sarcasm of netizens has some truth to it. It is actually difficult to define what is the best city. In 2018, a research institution ranked 338 cities above the prefecture level in China and ranked 15 new first-tier cities. Some cities are convinced by this ranking, while others are dissatisfied. In fact, not to mention that the concept of "best" is too big to be defined, even the smaller "urban livability" is difficult to explain clearly.

;

;For ordinary people, whether a city is livable is nothing more than commuting to and from work, making money and development, and basic necessities, food, housing and transportation, that is, income, consumption, and public services. In terms of work, the more developed the city's economy and the higher the income, the more livable it is. In terms of life, the more convenient, higher comfort and lower the cost of living, the more livable it is. These two aspects are related to the market. Outside the market are the public services provided by the government. Among the public services provided by the government, education and medical care can be provided by the market, but public security can only be provided by the government. Public security is the foundation for a livable city. Otherwise, no matter how much money you make, you can't save your life, so what's the point?

;

;Many times, these indicators are contradictory. The most typical example is that big cities have higher incomes and more development opportunities, but at the same time, housing prices and consumption in big cities are also more expensive, and the cost of living is very high. So, are big cities livable?

;

;First of all, there are more opportunities in big cities. Big cities have economies of scale. Under the economies of scale, there will be many services and jobs that cannot be maintained in small places. This is what many people say, they cannot find a job when they return to their hometown in a small town. Therefore, large cities with higher economic indicators can often provide more jobs and higher wages.

;

;From a consumption perspective, due to scale effects, big cities have richer ecosystems and many services will be cheaper. For example, if you want to see an expert account, living in a big city is just a matter of registration fee. You can find corresponding experts for all kinds of difficult and complicated diseases. But living in a small town also involves extra costs such as travel, accommodation and time off.

;

;Although houses in big cities are expensive, houses are also an asset. Even if you spend millions to buy a house, the money can still be recovered and liquidated. What's more, the prices of industrial products such as mobile phones, TVs, and automobiles are almost the same. This means that as long as a person's income can offset, or partially offset, the rent in a big city, his living standard in a big city will be higher and richer, his children will have more opportunities, and he will be able to spend more in emergencies. money. This is roughly what the word livable refers to. More and more people are flocking to big cities, which also proves that big cities are more livable.

;

;Of course, people's needs are complex and diverse. Some people want to live in a 200-square-meter house and play mahjong, but have no interest in opera or luxury goods. Some people are willing to live in a small house of 60 square meters in order for their children to receive a better education. Therefore, livability ultimately depends on the individual. Whether this is an abstract evaluation of the livability of large cities or small cities, we can only give one judgment principle. If we want to evaluate the livability comparison between specific cities, it is even more confusing.

;

;Anyone with statistical knowledge and research experience knows that data can lie. Not to mention the authenticity of the data, even if the data is real, there are too many ways to control the final conclusion in terms of indicator settings, sampling methods, data processing, and data interpretation.

;

;For example, set up a consumption indicator, consisting of online shopping activity, overseas shopping activity, takeout activity, and movie viewing frequency. Movie watching seems to reflect cultural consumption, but movies have a lipstick effect, which means that when the economy is bad, people will still entertain themselves, and even use entertainment more to comfort themselves, but they will turn to relatively cheap ones. It is possible that tourism consumption has gone down while movie consumption has increased. Therefore, the movie viewing indicator may not be objective. At least, it is not as authoritative and direct as the indicator of total social consumer goods per capita.

;

;There are many other indicators selection techniques. If public security is to be regarded as the most important indicator and a number of small indicators are set, then the world ranking of Chinese cities will definitely improve a lot, because Chinese people are kind-hearted and have omnipresent eyes. If you regard fireworks as indicators and set 10 small indicators, then New York's score may be improved a lot. After all, even Times Square is a mess.

;

;Moreover, urban livability indicators are often not independent. If one indicator improves, other indicators will also improve. For example, if a city has more universities, its medical conditions will also improve. Because universities often have medical schools, there are naturally more experts in medical schools. But it seems impossible to exclude this independence. Because studying in a better university and seeking medical treatment from experts are essentially the educational needs and medical needs of citizens. These are indeed two aspects of needs.

;

;So, by setting indicators, the livability evaluation of a city can indeed be greatly affected. The same is true for other cities' economic activity, urban development, best cities and other rankings. They can be used as a reference, but they do not need to be regarded as authoritative. Generally speaking, which city you decide to work and live in will be the most livable city for you.

; Fri, 20 Oct 2023 14:25:03 +0800 中职学校数量十年间大减，但“这不是坏事”http://www.infzm.com/contents/258931
;;2023-10-20 13:00:00;
;

;;

;

;On May 16, 2023, Hohhot, a vocational and technical school teacher introduced the professional situation to students . ;(Visual China/Photo);

;

;A set of data on secondary vocational education once attracted attention.

;

;Some media reported that in the past ten years, the number of secondary vocational schools has decreased by 3,039. Southern Weekend reporters combined data from the websites of the Ministry of Education and the Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security and found that from 2013 to 2022, the number of secondary vocational schools continued to decrease, with a cumulative decrease of 2,911.

;

;According to data from the websites of the two ministries and commissions, the number of secondary vocational schools in China will be 9,752 in 2022, less than half of the peak in the 1990s.

;

;Southern Weekend reporters found that the country’s adjustment of vocational education policies is the main reason for the decrease in the number of secondary vocational schools. In addition, the practical difficulties encountered in the development process of secondary vocational schools are also one of the reasons why various places have taken the initiative to merge and reduce schools. However, in recent years, with the changes in the layout of vocational education, secondary vocational schools have also ushered in new changes such as a substantial increase in the enrollment rate.

;

;Public information shows that, combined with the predictions of scholars, in the next few years, the gradual reduction, dissolution, merger and optimization of secondary vocational schools will continue to be a trend.

;

;;Anhui Province has the largest decrease;

;

;An easily confused concept is that in China, secondary vocational education is divided into four categories, including general technical secondary schools, vocational High schools, adult secondary schools and technical schools. In accordance with the Vocational Education Law and the current "three determinations" (functional configuration, internal organization and staffing) plan of the State Council, vocational high schools, general technical secondary schools and adult technical secondary schools are under the management of the education department, and technical schools are under the management of the human resources and social security department.

;

;It should be pointed out that the academic qualifications obtained after graduation from general technical secondary schools, vocational high schools, adult technical secondary schools and technical schools are all secondary education qualifications.

;

;Data from the Ministry of Education website shows that in 2013, the number of secondary vocational schools nationwide was 12,300. By 2022, this number dropped to 7,201. In the past ten years, the number of secondary vocational schools has decreased by 5,100 overall. .

;

;A closer look at the year-by-year data on the Ministry of Education’s website will reveal that from 2013 to 2020, the number of secondary vocational schools decreased each year by between 151 and 676. In 2021, the number of secondary vocational schools decreased by 2,602 compared with 2020, and there were obvious abnormalities in the range of data changes.

;

;In this regard, a note on the official website of the Ministry of Education shows that the statistics of secondary vocational colleges in 2021 and 2022 do not include technical schools managed by the human resources and social security departments.

;

;Southern Weekend reporters checked the official website of the Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security and found that including data from 2021 and 2022, the number of technical schools increased by 69 and 59 respectively. Combined with the decrease in the number of secondary vocational schools in the country from 2013 to 2022 compared with the previous year, the data shows that from 2013 to 2022, the number of secondary vocational schools nationwide decreased by 2,911 in ten years.

;

;However, Southern Weekend reporters inquired about the official data released by the education departments and statistics departments of 31 provinces (autonomous regions and municipalities) across the country from 2012 to 2022. Whether each province (autonomous region and municipality) plans to collect data The standards for entering technical schools are not uniform.

;

;However, looking at the overall situation, nationwide, except for the Tibet Autonomous Region, which has a slight increase in the number of secondary vocational colleges (an increase of 7) on the original basis, the remaining provinces (autonomous regions and municipalities) are all. downward trend. The number of secondary vocational schools in Anhui Province has decreased the most, with a decrease of 216 in ten years, a decrease of approximately 44%. Henan Province followed, with a decrease of 198.

;

;In the past ten years, the number of universities has decreased by more than 100 in 10 provinces. Except for Heilongjiang, Shandong, Guangdong, and Zhejiang, the rest are all in the central and western regions.

;

;In comparison, Qinghai, Ningxia and other places have experienced single-digit declines over the past ten years due to factors such as insufficient construction of secondary vocational schools, and the change is not significant.

;

;;

;

;On June 25, 2022, in a clothing production company in Tongren, Guizhou, students majoring in clothing design at the Yuping Dong Autonomous County Secondary Vocational School were processing clothing. ;(Visual China/Photo);

;

;;Policy adjustment is the main reason;

;

;Secondary vocational school It once played an important role in China's economic development. Its number experienced explosive growth in the late 1980s, from 2,760 in 1978 to more than 20,000 in 1990, an increase of nearly eight times.

;

;However, by the end of the 20th century, with the combined effects of multiple factors such as industrial restructuring, tightening of the employment environment, and expansion of college enrollment, the development of secondary vocational education gradually declined because it was difficult to adapt to the needs of the market and employers.

;

;Official data shows that since 1999, the number of secondary vocational schools has been declining year by year, with only a slight increase between 2004 and 2008.

;

;During this period, in 2007, the Ministry of Education issued the "Notice on Further Improving the Enrollment Management of Various Types of Colleges and Universities", which stipulated that the corresponding enrollment plan for colleges and universities to recruit secondary vocational graduates should not exceed the number of fresh graduates of secondary vocational schools that year. 5% of students. This proportion limit actually clarifies the employment orientation of secondary vocational education.

;

;The main reason for the decrease in the number of secondary vocational schools is the adjustment of national policies.

;

;In 2014 and 2019, the State Council issued the "Decision on Accelerating the Development of Modern Vocational Education" (hereinafter referred to as the "Decision") and the "Notice on Issuing the National Vocational Education Reform Implementation Plan" respectively. It is proposed to “encourage high-quality schools to integrate school resources and optimize the layout and structure of secondary vocational education through mergers, trusteeships, cooperative education, etc.”

;

;After the "Decision" was promulgated, the Beijing Municipal Education Commission announced the corresponding implementation opinions of Beijing, requiring the number of secondary vocational schools in the city to be adjusted from 116 to about 60, a reduction of nearly half.

;

;Henan started optimizing the layout of secondary vocational schools in 2015, and integrated a number of "weak, small and scattered" schools in the form of cancellation, merger, and transfer. Jiangxi also introduced a new policy for secondary vocational education in 2015, proposing to merge more than 200 secondary vocational schools within three years.

;

;Also in 2015, Guangxi proposed that "by 2020, the number of secondary vocational schools in the region will be adjusted from the current 333 to about 240."

;

;In September 2020, nine departments including the Ministry of Education jointly issued the "Action Plan for Improving the Quality of Vocational Education (2020-2023)" (hereinafter referred to as the "Plan"). Based on the original policy It is further proposed to "comprehensively verify the basic conditions for running secondary vocational schools, integrate 'empty, small, scattered and weak' schools, and optimize the layout of secondary vocational schools."

;

;In addition to the adjustment of national policies, the difficulties encountered by secondary vocational schools in their own development are also one of the reasons for the reduction in the number of schools.

;

;In fact, before the state promulgated relevant policies, local governments had already taken measures to reduce the number of secondary vocational schools, which directly pointed to practical problems in the development of secondary vocational education.

;

;As early as the beginning of the 21st century, in order to meet the needs of Beijing’s urban function adjustment and industrial structure upgrading, the Beijing Municipal Education Commission merged a number of small-scale, low-efficiency schools with unclear professional characteristics.

;

;“This is not a bad thing. Only by merging schools with poor quality and low enrollment can we improve the quality and attractiveness of secondary vocational colleges.” Vice Chairman of China Development Research Foundation Fang Jin, the secretary-general, once said publicly.

;

;;The transformation of secondary vocational schools pays more attention to quality;

;

;“The decrease in the number of secondary vocational colleges has a certain relationship with the transformation of secondary vocational education, because the government may China pays more attention to quality rather than quantity." Xu Hui, a doctoral candidate in sociology at the University of Jena in Germany and a researcher at the Sino-German Research Center for Skills and Social Development, told Southern Weekend reporters that this reduction in quantity may help concentrate resources and improve the quality of education. , to meet today’s ever-changing professional needs. According to Xu Hui’s observation, under the transformation, secondary vocational education has greatly improved in terms of curriculum diversity, technology upgrading, and career guidance.

;

;The ensuing increase in attractiveness is also the result of policy changes. One of the key points is the substantial increase in the enrollment rate.

;

;PhD candidate Jiang Beijia and scientific research assistant Fan Yilin of the National Education Macro Policy Research Institute of East China Normal University published a paper "Policy Changes in Vocational Education for Higher Education: Context, Logic and "Mirror", sorted out relevant policy documents and found that since the "National Medium and Long-term Education Reform and Development Plan (2010-2020)" issued in 2010, it was first proposed to separate the enrollment of higher vocational examinations from the general college entrance examination. The "National Vocational Education Reform Implementation Plan" clearly states for the first time that "the establishment of a vocational education college entrance examination system" will be completely liberated from the previously restricted enrollment rate in secondary vocational schools.

;

;At present, the main channels for secondary vocational school graduates to obtain undergraduate degrees include consistent training, vocational education college entrance examination, junior college to bachelor's degree, etc.

;

;The smooth flow of channels for further education has led to an increase in the admission rate of secondary vocational schools. Data released by education departments in many places show that the enrollment rate of secondary vocational schools in recent years has generally exceeded 80%. Taking Shenzhen, which has developed secondary vocational education, as an example, the "Shenzhen Secondary Vocational Education Quality Report 2023" shows that in 2022, the number of graduates from Shenzhen's secondary vocational schools will be 12,485, and the number of students entering higher education will be 11,173, with the enrollment rate reaching 89.49%.

;

;However, Xu Hui also pointed out that a high secondary vocational education promotion rate can provide students with more opportunities, but a careful balance is also needed to ensure that the quality and resources of secondary vocational education are not ignored.

;

;In February 2022, at a press conference held by the Ministry of Education to introduce the work related to promoting the high-quality development of modern vocational education, Chen Ziji, Director of the Department of Vocational Education and Adult Education of the Ministry of Education, further explained that optimizing the quality of secondary vocational education The layout structure is mainly achieved through measures such as cancellation, merger, transformation, trusteeship, land replacement, and group school running.

;

;This means that in the future, the number of secondary vocational schools nationwide may continue to decrease.
